characters: --THE FUSILLADE BECOMES FURIOUS, INSANE. BULLETS SHATTER
162B BACK ON-- DAN AND WADE-- UNDER THE OVERHANG
EXT. RACING ACROSS THE RANGE-- DAY
UNDER THE OVERHANG-- DAN AND WADE--
EXT. PRISON WAGON, EVANS RANCH --LATE AFTERNOON
THE HORSEMEN RIDE AWAY AS WILLIAM ENTERS THE FLAMING BARN
INT./EXT. PRISON WAGON, EVANS RANCH --LATE AFTERNOON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wearing longjohns and boots, DAN BUSTS OUT THE DOOR, movi toward the man fanning fire at the barn--

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: No-- Please-- stop!-- A RIFLE BUTT SMASHES DAN’S HEAD. He tumbles off the porch the dirt, losing his gun, one boot coming off, revealing- A MISSING LEFT FOOT. William runs past Alice and Mark on the porch and his fat on the ground as-- THE BARN EXPLODES IN FLAMES. Dan jerks back on his rigged boot, gets upright and lunges toward the barn. THE FIRST HORSEMAN, bears down on him.

dialogues.speaker: HORSEMAN, (TUCKER)
dialogues.text: -- You have a week, Evans. Then we burn the house.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: William!

dialogues.speaker: FLAMES LICK THE RAFTERS. SMOKE.
dialogues.text: FOUR HORSES tied in stalls, crazy with fear. William frees two of them, Dan untangles the others and l them out, grabbing equipment, tossing saddles out the doo Then Dan notices WILLIAM HAS TURNED BACK INSIDE. William struggles to drag A HUGE SACK OF FEED and some to We see above him, the burning roof sags, flaming pieces o wood raining-- it’s about to collapse-- DAN LEAPS AND GRABS HIS BOY and drags him toward the door fists swinging. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: --Let go! It’s the last we got! They fall to the ground as THE BARN COLLAPSES in a fiery mass, sparks showering down. Alice and Mark run toward th

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: ..-You alright? Will turns from his father to see- THE TWO HORSEMEN ridin away. Dawn light beginning to touch the sky. WILLIAM LUNGES FOR THE REMINGTON on the ground-- --but Dan is faster and puts his hand on the weapon.

dialogues.speaker: DAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’ll take care of this.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: No you won’t. ...You don’t take care of nothing. Tears stand in William’s eyes. Dan takes the gun and starts walking back toward the hous He passes Alice and Mark, avoiding their eyes.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: The herd is over the ridge by now. Get cleaned up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan yanks open a drawer and grabs a shirt. His arms and c streaked in SOOT... Out the bedroom window the sun is creeping over the rocky horizon. His eyes fall upon a beautiful ANTIQUE BROOCH in a drawer He examines it. It is gold. And he pockets it and turns, finding himself looking at William, watching him. William turns away, and crosses to his bedroom. Dan moves to a basin at the back of the house.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: You lied to me, Dan. Dan turns to face Alice. ALICE (CONT’D) You told me we made payments to Hollander. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: We did. Some. (off look, heading inside) How do you think we bought feed, Alice? Three months water. Medicine for Mark. I had a choice between our family and paying it down.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: We’ re supposed to make decisions together.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Would you have made it different?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Dan.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: We can’t make it rain together. Or turn dust into grass. And we can’t hold back winter. It’s too bad the doctors at Essex saved so much of my leg. I read the pension act pays by the pound now. Dan leans against the wall, pulling on his boots. Tears come to Alice’s eyes.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Stop looking at me like that. Mark appears in the hall. Dan crosses back to his bedroom pulling on a clean shirt.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: (as Dan passes) .»..You gonna tell the Marshal what those men did?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (from his bedroom) Marshal ain’t doing shit.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: William.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: First thing I’m gonna do, Mark, is take you boys and round up the herd. ...Then I’m going to town. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON-- WILLIAM in his room, gettting dressed, listeni with jaundice as his father reassures Mark. He pockets a of cards and his dime novel.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: What you gonna do in town?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: I’m gonna tell Hollander to make this right. I’m gonna tell him he needs to pay for a new barn.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Maybe we should just shoot him, like Will says. Alice meets eyes with Dan who grabs HIS SPENCER RIFLE and brushes past William on his way to the door.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: ....-Let’s go. We got cattle to get.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --atop a magnificent BLACK MARE, staring at something. Be has a ruggedly handsome face, but what strikes you first his focus. He’s very still, eyes on fire, low to the hors The horse inches forward. Hooves hardly make a sound. REVERSE TO REVEAL-- A RED-TAILED HAWK, perched only fifte feet away on the limb of a dead tree.

dialogues.speaker: WE ARE
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON-- WADE makes a low ‘s’ sound and his horse halts Wade sketches the bird on A SMALL LEDGER PAD with a PENCI capturing its form with quick gestures. Suddenly: A noise The hawk FLIES OFF. Wade watches it shrink into the sky. A darkness fills his eyes. PULL BACK TO REVEAL: CHARLIE PRINCE (31), a pale eyed out coming up behind Wade. A PAIR OF SCHOFIELDS on his legs. ...he stops his horse respectfully, a few yards back.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE PRINCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Coach is headed for Bisbee, Boss. Girded with iron. Pinks on top. Double shotguns and a Gatlin-- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Charlie trails off as Wade rides to the tree, tears his SKETCH and pins it to a BRANCH where the hawk had been perched. His eyes flick to-- A DISTANT STAGECOACH, a speck in the valley, kicking dust Wade turns his horse and trots past Charlie... Charlie Prince glances at the drawing. HOLD ON: THE SKETC FLUTTERING IN THE BREEZE as Prince follows down the hill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie Prince follows as-- Ben Wade rides down past a CLUSTER OF BOULDERS where his outfit awaits him: JORGENSEN (45): Massive arms and legs. A bear of a man. CAMPOS (38): The marksman. Loads a cradled MONSTER RIFLE. KINTER (34): A soulless butcher with deadened eyes. SUTHERLAND (42): An explosives expert. He supervises as-- TIGHE (28): his protege, loading TNT in a saddle bag. JACKSON (35): Powerful and dangerous. A friend and former cellmate of -- TOMMY DARDEN (28): Battle-scarred handsome face. A BOWIE KNIFE in his hand. He is looking to replace Wade and lead gang someday, soon. But in the meantime, he amuses himsel making trouble with-- NEZ (32): An Apache renegade. He speaks little English an uses it rarely. But he is a great shot, a brilliant rider a merciless fighter. He’s been with Wade since the beginn Darden taunts Nez with his long knife, oblivious to Wade’ approach-- He and Jackson trade a chuckle. Nez looks at Wade. And Wade looks at Darden hard.

dialogues.speaker: DARDEN
dialogues.text: Ben. Darden slips the knife back in the sheaf. Wade turns his eyes to the road below. ...and here comes the STAGECOACH, GETTING CLOSER. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Wade turns to Charlie and gives a nod... ...and the gang surges behind Charlie Prince. As everyone rides past him, Campos the marksman looks back to Wade. W nods to a CLUSTER OF BOULDERS nearby. Campos climbs off his horse and scales the rocks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: GALLOPING HOOVES thundering down a desert road. A team of FOUR HORSES pulling an ARMORED STAGECOACH throu barren stretch of land. We see a fancy EYE LOGO stamped upon the door with the fa Pinkerton slogan printed below: The Eye That Never Sleeps There are SIX PINKERTONS riding. Two in front, two ona mounted “tailgun” platform and two inside, peering out sl THE VETERAN DRIVER pushes the horses. Sitting beside him is the sixth man and the group’s leade BYRON McELROY (55). McElroy is clearly not a Pinkerton, a hardly dressed or groomed like one. He’s got snake-like e He holds a mean-looking, twelve-gauge HAMMER SHOTGUN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan’s crouched next to his horse, gazing at one of his co which has collapsed upon the arid earth, gasping... Dan glances up at the sky, then he pulls out the BROOCH i his grimy hands. Twenty feet away, William sits on his horse behind Dan, shuffling HIS DECK OF CARDS.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: You gonna hock that? Dan pockets it.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Someday, William. You walk in my shoes, you might understand.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I’m never walking in your shoes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Mark calls out from a nearby ridge:

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Tracks over here! Dan takes the SPENCER RIFLE from his saddle. Standing ove the dying creature. Looking in its eyes as he FIRES...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SHOT ECHOES faintly through the foothills. Wade peers around behind him. He shrugs it off, focusing back on his outfit below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McElroy stiffens as-- WADE’S GANG appears suddenly on the road ahead coming straight at the coach, head on. McElroy sees them and grimaces. Cocking both pins on his SHOTGUN.

dialogues.speaker: MCELROY
dialogues.text: Here we go. With proficiency, the other Pinkertons flip down or slide across several ARMORED STEEL PLATES in front of them.. ...and in the next second, the outlaws and the Pinkertons clash in a violent FUSILLADE OF BULLETS. TWO PINKERTONS MAN THE GATLIN mounted at the rear. Unfortunately it is exactly where the gang isn’t (they’re coming from the front) and they have no shot. The Pinkertons fire as Wade’s gang rides straight at them game of chicken. Bullets exploding around him, McELROY AIMS AT ONE OF THE OUTLAWS RIDING IN FRONT. -- BANG! -- With one shot he blows the outlaw off his hor As the gang swarms around them -- RATATATAT. PINKERTONS F THE GATLIN, spraying the gang, mowing down another outlaw Suddenly, one of the Pinkertons on the gatlin falls back, shot by-- CAMPOS, at his sniper’s perch-- rifle smoking. The remaining Pinkerton cradles the ammo and swings the b brass gun at Campos, twisting the crank. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Campos dives for cover amid a hail of bullets. Like fighter pilots, the gang wheels in unison back aroun catch the coach on another pass. CHARLIE PRINCE GALLOPS from the other side of the coach a takes out the remaining Gatlin operator with two shots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McElroy and the Pinkertons defend the coach valiantly. Ta cover behind their ARMORED PLATES as the coach rattles al the road. Another Pinkerton climbs from a hatch and re-ma the Gatlin. He sends a spray of bullets toward the oncomi gang-- another man falls. The last Pinkerton (MOONS) inside the stagecoach takes ai through the gun slit. He manages to HIT JORGENSEN. The big man snaps backwards, falling to the ground, while clutching HIS EAR... CLOSE ON -- MCELROY’S EYES watching Sutherland and Tighe approach from the driver’s side.

dialogues.speaker: MCELROY
dialogues.text: (to driver) Get. Down. Now! McElroy swings his shotgun over the driver, who ducks, an aims at Tighe but then aims lower, at his saddle bag-- He fires and-- BOOM!-- TIGHE AND HORSE EXPLODE IN MID-STR THE COACH LURCHES INTO A NARROW PASS, making it hard for gang to follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade watches, amused, his eyes on McElroy as he directs t coach to make a run for a narrow pass. Wade smiles. These two have history. Then, he notices-- A SCRAWNY HERD OF CATTLE on the other side of an outcroppin Forty cows and bulls nibbling on what little they can fin A thought flickers across Wade’s mind. And he abruptly wheels his horse towards the animals.  14 15 16

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan and his sons have stopped their horses over the ridge listening to the GUNSHOTS. Sounds like a warzone. Dan pulls out his SPENCER RIFLE, riding in front.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Stay behind me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE STAGECOACH RACES through the narrow pass, A PLUME OF rising. McElroy squints, seeing-- A HERD OF CATTLE stampeding toward him. And Ben Wade driv them unflinchingly with a stock whip.

dialogues.speaker: MCELROY
dialogues.text: Pull up, kid. Pull up! The driver stares at the cattle, frozen. Imagine the bull in Pamplona, only you’re driving into it. McElroy lunges the reins pulling hard as HOOVES and HORNS collide. The STAGECOACH lists to one side, you can feel the weight this iron carriage. The FRONT AXLE SNAPS. Horses break fr The STAGECOACH NOSES INTO AN EMBANKMENT AND FLIPS, rollin end over end like a semi on the turnpike. McElroy, the driver, and injured Pinkertons catapult to the air. ANGLE ON: THE OUTLAWS hounding unfortunate survivors. Darden touches his BOWIE KNIFE to the chest of A PINKERTO

dialogues.speaker: PINKERTON
dialogues.text: Oh God, Mr. Wade. Please. I got a wife and three kids. Please don’t--

dialogues.speaker: DARDEN
dialogues.text: What did you call me, boy? I ain’t Ben Wade. My name is Tommy Darden. Legend with a blade. Soon to run this outfit. Say my name. Say it.

dialogues.speaker: PINKERTON
dialogues.text: ...I can’t remember it... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Darden twists the knife as the driver howls. Charlie Prince wields his TWO SCHOFIELDS like the Reaper, singing and doing a soft shoe as he puts two Pinkertons o of their misery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: moves slowly, confidently toward the coach, unimpressed b the carnage. Most of the coach horses have run off. A cou are on the ground. A few cattle wander about dazed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the dust settles. The outlaws find McElroy pulling him in the dirt, holding his leg, reaching with his other han for his HAMMER SHOTGUN.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE PRINCE
dialogues.text: Morning, Pinkerton. Name’s Charlie Prince. I expect you heard of me.

dialogues.speaker: MCELROY
dialogues.text: I heard of a balled-up whore named Charlie Princess. That you, missy. Darden and Jackson get a chuckle out of this -- Charlie Prince smiles, then fires a SHOT into McElroy’s gut... ...and McElroy just GRUNTS.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE PRINCE
dialogues.text: I hate Pinkertons. ANGLE ON: BEN WADE riding up now, the gang clearing a pat He stops before McElroy and they share a look...

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: When’d your hair turn all gray, Byron. McElroy says nothing. Wade gives a nod to Sutherland who rushes up to the PADLOCKED STEEL DOOR on the stagecoach, SATCHEL OF EXPLOSIVES under his arm. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WADE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I heard, Byron, that your boss, Al Pinkerton, president of the most feared protection agency in all the world, home of the eye that never sleeps, well, I heard he got an infection from biting his own tongue ...and died last month. That true? (turns) Makes you think, don’t it Charlie? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Some of the gang laughs. As Sutherland sets EXPLOSIVES, W circles the toppled coach, admiring the ARMORED PLATES.

dialogues.speaker: WADE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Al spared no expense on this one, Byron. Probably cheaper just to let me rob the damned thing.

dialogues.speaker: MCELROY
dialogues.text: If you’re gonna kill me, I’d just as soon get to it.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: (dismounts) I’m not gonna kill you. Not like this.

dialogues.speaker: MCELROY
dialogues.text: You let me live, it won’t change a thing. I’1l come for you.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: Be disappointed if you didn’t. BOOM! THE EXPLOSIVES blow the STEEL DOOR off its hinges. Moons lies, groggy and bloody on the floor. Darden jumps past Sutherland and inside the stagecoach (stepping over Moons, who plays dead). He reappears with STRONG BOX. He shoots off the PADLOCK and OPENS the box.. ...to reveal DOZENS OF CASH ROLLS inside. Railroad money. whoops with joy, tossing the CASH ROLLS to Jackson who pu the CASH ROLLS into SADDLE BAGS. Wade watches the pair closely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...From the crest of the ridge, Mark waves to Dan and William. Mark sees the HERD and the STAGECOACH WRECKAGE, OUTLAWS swarming around it. Coming up the rise, Dan goes still at the sight of this. He signals silence to Mark. Mark’s horse fidgets. Some rocks tumble down the ridge.  20 21 3:10 TO YUMA - TAN - 1.23.07 13.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...the robbery is almost over now. Darden emptying out th last of the STRONG BOX. Nez packing the CASH in SADDLE BA Wade glances at the wounded Jorgensen who’s tied a BANDAN around his ear. He gives the boss a nod, he’s okay. All of a sudden ...CLICK! Darden freezes, hearing a PISTO from behind. The rest of the gang goes still, guns ready. Moons climbs out from inside the coach, grabbing Darden, hostage-style. He is a blood drenched mess.

dialogues.speaker: MOONS
dialogues.text: I’1l ask you to put down the money.

dialogues.speaker: DARDEN
dialogues.text: ‘not a good play, friend.

dialogues.speaker: MOONS
dialogues.text: ...Step back now. All of you. Hands up. Or he dies. No one in the gang moves a muscle. Darden tries to free himself but Moons holds tight, cocking his weapon to Dard temple. Darden looks at Wade.

dialogues.speaker: DARDEN
dialogues.text: ...Shit. -- Wade quick-draws his COLT “PEACEMAKER” -- BANG! -- AND SHOOTS DARDEN who spins violently-- grabbing his NECK and falling to the ground, mortally wounded. BANG! ANOTHER SHOT snaps Moons’ head back. He falls to the ground, dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s obviously the first time the children have ever seen killing. Mark is shaken... William fascinated... ...and we see that Dan’s all too aware of this.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: He is fast... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Back up. Quietly. William. Rocks start to slide as Dan moves them to a less exposed point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BACK AT THE COACH, WADE reloads his smoking pistol as he speaks to Darden stuggling for last breaths on the dirt.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: ...Well, Tommy. It appears there was a Pink in that coach you didn’t see. Now I don’t know if Charlie told you, but we got a few rules in this outfit. And this sad outcome, well, this is what happens when you put us all at risk. You were weak. Some rocks fall in the distance, from where Dan and his s are making a retreat. A boy coughs. The whole gang hears

dialogues.speaker: CLICK
dialogues.text: Ten guns whip to the ridge. Cocked and leveled at Dan. Wade leaps on his his horse, GALLOPING up to the ridge WI CHARLIE PRINCE AND CAMPOS RIGHT BEHIND HIM. Jackson starts to pick up the money... ...but Nez gets th first. Placing the SADDLE BAGS full of cash onto his hors The other outlaws watch him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan rides in front of his two boys as Wade and Charlie Pr approach. Wade and Dan stare at one another.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: Morning.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Those are my cattle. I want them back.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE PRINCE
dialogues.text: Careful, rancher. That’s Ben Wade you’re talking to. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: We see William, awestruck.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: I need them back. They’re all I’ve got.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: I don’t want your herd. But I’m going to need those horses. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE PRINCE
dialogues.text: (moves forward) So you don’t do anything foolish. Dan sheaths his rifle and gives his boys a look. They dismount and Charlie Prince takes their horses.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: You'll find them on the trail to Bisbee. The two outlaws turn, taking the horses, riding down the leaving Dan his boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...we FOLLOW Wade, Prince and Campos as they ride away.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPOS
dialogues.text: (quietly, to Prince) What’s in Bisbee.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE PRINCE
dialogues.text: ‘Aint you thirsty. Charlie rides past the WRECKAGE and the gang falls in beh Charging down the road. Jackson lags, circling Darden’s b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minutes later. Dan leads his sons through the cattle whic are milling about the WRECKAGE. Dan looks for survivors. DEAD BODIES. A few DEAD STEER. And one of the HORSES that pulled the coach, also dead. William spots something by Bill Moons’ corpse... Three SPENT SHELLS from WADE’S PISTOL. William picks up o of the spent shells. Gazing at it like it’s treasure. ANGLE ON: DAN as he comes upon McElroy in the dirt, bleeding... trying to get up...

dialogues.speaker: MCELROY
dialogues.text: Ahhh Dammit! (to Dan) Get me on my feet. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: I think you’re in pretty bad shape, Mister. Maybe you should--

dialogues.speaker: MCELROY
dialogues.text: Get me on my damned feet! ...-As Dan tries to lift him, McElroy grunts and gets upr but then his legs give out and he crumbles to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Mark, William-- (pointing to the wreck) Bring me one of them boards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben Wade rides, shadowed by Charlie Prince on his horse. The rest of the gang is nowhere in sight... ...the two men are approaching a remote town -- A dozen WOODEN STRUCTURES strewn upon a crossroad. Small flags stuck in the dirt, trace the intended path of train line from the mountains. A sign says: ANNOUNCING THE BISBEE-CONTENTION LINE. A small surveying crew works, laying out the flags.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE OUTLAWS survey the town as they ride through. There’s SALOON (“Hollander’s”) and around the corner A VETERINARI OFFICE and a BLACKSMITH. A FEW TOWNSFOLK move along, none paying much attention. EXT. MARSHAL’S OFFICE, BISBEE - DAY At the end of the street sits the MARSHAL’S OFFICE, sever horses tied to the side. Wade dismounts at the corner, noticing a BARMAID emerge from a saloon... ...this is EMMA NELSON (31). She glances at Wade, meeting eyes, then turns to sweep the porch. A connection. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Charlie Prince ties his horse further down the block from Wade. He glances at Sutherland across the street, tending his horse near a Blacksmith’s shop. Off Wade’s glance, Charlie starts to the Marshals’s offic FOLLOWING CHARLIE’S BOOTS-- With each step, his gait chan from the stride of an outlaw to the amble of a cowpoke. INT./EXT. MARSHAL’S OFFICE, BISBEE - DAY In the doorway looking out, GRAYSON BUTTERFIELD (36) star at the horizon. His face sour with anxiety. He wears the official suit of the Southern Railroad. Just inside MARSHAL WEATHERS (42) checks his watch. HIS DEPUTY, KANE, rolls a cigarette in the back.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHAL
dialogues.text: They’ re probably just late, Mister Butterfield. Charlie Prince leans in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: BUTTERFIELD
dialogues.text: Pinkertons don’t run late, Marshal. That’s why they’re paid fourteen dollars a day.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHAL
dialogues.text: Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE PRINCE
dialogues.text: ...Well ...I think maybe a coach headed for here got itself held up in a canyon ten miles back. By Ben Wade himself, I think.

dialogues.speaker: BUTTERFIELD
dialogues.text: God Dammit!..

dialogues.speaker: MARSHAL WEATHERS
dialogues.text: How did you know it was Wade? OUTSIDE-- BEN WADE watches as-- Emma crosses inside the saloon with her dust pan. Ben pulls his hat low and walks down the plank sidewalk, moving closer to the voices in the Marshal’s office... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE PRINCE
dialogues.text: ‘Can’t say I know it was him. But I saw a Mexican sharpshooter, and an Apache.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: ...desus Christ. Did you see the “Hand of God”?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE PRINCE
dialogues.text: ...What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: His pistol.

dialogues.speaker: BUTTERFIELD
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you do something?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE PRINCE
dialogues.text: There was a lot of weapons, Mister. And they was shooting bullets. The Marshal and Kane grab their rifles and move to the do Butterfield follows. EXT. MARSHAL’S OFFICE-- CONTINUOUS The Marshal and others blow right by Prince as they mount their horses. Wade watches from up the street.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHAL WEATHERS
dialogues.text: (to Prince) Where you fellas from anyway?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE PRINCE
dialogues.text: Prairie Cattle Company. Boss purchased ten thousand head in Mexico, hired us to drive them in. The Marshal nods, satisfied and spurs his horse, gallopin off, down the street. INT. HOLLANDER’S MERCANTILE -- CONTINUOUS Watching out a window, TUCKER (last seen burning Dan’s ba watches the Marshal and Butterfield ride off.

dialogues.speaker: TUCKER
dialogues.text: Something’s going on with the railroad man. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: GLENN HOLLANDER (45), the town’s well-groomed saloon owne and entrepreneur looks up from his inventory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seeing the street is clear, Charlie Prince nods to Wade. Wade crosses, heading toward the saloon doors. Charlie follows, passing a look to Sutherland. And Sutherland nods to-- Campos, who’s in an alley with Jorgensen, helping the big man hold a bloody rag to his damaged ear. Sutherland also signals Kinter and Nez behind the saloon. One by one, the outlaws amble toward the saloon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade peers over the SALOON DOORS. The place is empty save old timer. A few tables and chairs, with a bar on one wal Emma turns to see Wade. She keeps her eyes on him as he s inside, his crew following. Most come in from the BACK DO Campos and Jackson escort the old timer out. Wade takes a place at the head of the bar...

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: Whiskey. Emma starts pouring them each a shot of WHISKEY. Gradually working her way up to Wade.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE PRINCE
dialogues.text: Here’s to the boss. He leads us to the loot and to success. We lost three men today and that’s too bad.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: Two died fighting. One was weak. We’ re only as strong as our weakest. Tommy was weak. Wade downs his shot with the men. He turns and meets eyes with Jackson. Jackson looks away. With Nez’s help, Charlie distributes shares from the day’ job. A stack of cash to each man. It is a careful process Charlie looks at Wade and Emma, then looks to Nez. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Nez gets up and leads the gang out the back door. Wade’s eyes hold on Emma. Charlie leans beside him. CHARLIE PRINCE (CONT’D) That Marshal’s only half stupid. He’s gonna be back soon. Wade just looks at him. Outside the window, the gang rides off. CHARLIE PRINCE (CONT’D) They’ re going across the border. I won’t be far. I’1l wait for you.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: Okay, Charlie. Charlie exits. Wade finishes his drink. Emma cleans.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: I’ve seen you someplace before.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Have you.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: You ever work for a blind Irishman in Dodge City.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: I was a singer. Best time I ever had, my whole life.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: What made you quit. Emma turns away, collecting the SHOT GLASSES... ..-and Wade follows her around the counter.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: I got to coughing too much. Doctor said I should find a drier climate.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: I spent more money in that joint, I tell you. Remember a girl, her name was Velvet. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: (her back to him) Nobody forgets Velvet. Wade reaches out and touches the back of her neck... Emma hasn’t been touched like that in a while.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: You know, you look kind of skinny.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: I feel skinny.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: That’s all right. I don’t mind skinny girls, long as they have green eyes to make up for it. Do you have green eyes. She turns, showing him her BROWN EYES...

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: That’s all right... They don’t have to be green.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan and William carry McElroy along a trail on a STRETCHE made of a stagecoach panel. Dan’s in front. Mark walks alongside, glancing at McElroy’s WOUND. McElro clutches a rag to it and glares at the sky, muttering.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: ...You think they lied? You think they stole our horses.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Ben Wade don’t need our shit horses.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Watch your mouth. Cresting a ridge, they come upon-- Their horses tied to a tree. Dan is surprised.

dialogues.speaker: 37A MOMENTS LATER-- AT THE HORSES
dialogues.text: William helps his father prop a growling McElroy onto Dan horse. As Mark mounts up. Dan turns to William. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: ...Take your brother and round up the cattle. Don’t push them. I can’t afford any more dropping. William spits, looking at something, then mounts his hors

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: ...Here comes the Cavalry. Dan turns to see-- Marshal Weathers riding up with Kane, Crawley and Butterfield. He turns back to his son.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Do as I said. William spurs his horse and leads Mark off, looking back Butterfield dismounts, crossing to McElroy.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHAL
dialogues.text: He from the coach?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: The only one who made it. It was Ben Wade.

dialogues.speaker: BUTTERFIELD
dialogues.text: Mister McElroy. Can you hear me. He needs attention.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: Get him on my horse.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHAL
dialogues.text: You see which way they rode, Evans?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Looked like they were headed to Bisbee... With dark faces, Butterfield looks to the Marshal and the realize...

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. EMMA’S BEDROOM-- SALOON - DAY Wade relaxes on a chair, wearing only pants. He sketches who’s lounging naked in bed in a small room above the sal She watches him work for several moments, grinning. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: His eyes meet hers. There are sparks between these two. S rolls toward him. He reaches out -- touches her ivory ski Out a window, Wade glances at-- Butterfield, Dan, the Mar and his Deputies riding into town, McElroy in tow. Wade turns away from the window. It doesn’t worry him.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: ...There’s a town south of the border... A pretty little pueblucho on the river. Folks would pay good money there to hear a white woman sing.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: ....Yeah, imagine me shinning down to Mexico with Ben Wade on my arm.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: I’m not wanted in Mexico. Emma studies him, wondering if he’s sincere. She breaks a smile, like he’s pulling her leg. But his eyes are still.

dialogues.speaker: WADE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jump out that back window with me. Emma stares at him, mystified, then laughs.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: You’ re crazy. She smiles and starts to rolls out of bed, but he pulls h back to him and into the soft bed. INT. DOC POTTER’S OFFICE, BISBEE - DAY A loud knocking. DOC POTTER (42) shuffles toward the door UNLOCKS it. Kane and Dan move in holding McElroy in their arms. Butterfield follows. Dan sets McElroy on a BIG SLAB

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Coach got held up.

dialogues.speaker: DOC POTTER
dialogues.text: What’s his name.

dialogues.speaker: BUTTERFIELD
dialogues.text: Byron McElroy. He’s a bounty hunter under contract with the Pinkertons. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Butterfield looks about the room. A veterinarian's office crosses to the window. Outside the saloon, the Marshal and Crawley begin to sear the village for Wade.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: (crossing to the door) I best get out there.

dialogues.speaker: DOC POTTER
dialogues.text: You've lost a lot of blood, Mister McElroy. I’m gonna need to do a little stitching on your--

dialogues.speaker: MCELROY
dialogues.text: Shut your mouth and do the same to my gut. Doc Potter blinks. He notes the many scarred-over bullet holes and gashes on McElroy’s chest. Dan crosses to the door, watching as-- Kane joins the Marshal and Crawley as they continue movin through the town, guns drawn.

dialogues.speaker: BACK INSIDE--
dialogues.text: DOC POTTER (CONT’D) What I’m about to do is going to hurt like a sonofabitch... (to Butterfield) ...-Hold him please. Butterfield moves to pin McElroy, but...

dialogues.speaker: MCELROY
dialogues.text: Don’t touch me. Doc Potter dives a LONG PAIR OF TWEEZERS into McElroy’s wound. McElroy grunts fiercely, eyes welling, holding his glare with Potter. Plink. The bullet’s out. Doc Potter drops it in a dish. McElroy turns, noticing the ANIMAL CHARTS on all the wall

dialogues.speaker: MCELROY
dialogues.text: What the fuck kind of Doctor are you anyway? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DOC POTTER
dialogues.text: Nice to have a conversation with a patient once in a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan makes his way around the corner from Potter’s place, moving toward Hollander’s mercantile. He sees-- Hollander talking to a clerk, through an open side door. Dan steps pick up speed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawley stops in front of Wade’s Horse, runs his hand ove the animal. This animal is not from Bisbee

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Marshal and Kane stand at the entrance of the saloon. They look about until they hear a whistle from outside. They turn to see-- Crawley pointing to Wade’s horse in fr of the Boarding House. They move quickly to the Boarding House, weapons drawn.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. HOLLANDER’S MERCANTILE -- CONTINUOUS Dan enters. He meets eyes with Tucker, who assists a cler with inventory. On the other side of the room, Hollander a Ledger book in his bag and pulls on his coat, watching his window.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLANDER
dialogues.text: What the hell are they looking for?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: ...-Ben Wade. He held up the payroll coach. I was there.

dialogues.speaker: TUCKER
dialogues.text: Fuck off, cripple.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: I want to talk, Mister Hollander. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Hollander moves toward the door, his eyes across the stre watching the search. He checks his sidearm.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLANDER
dialogues.text: Ben Wade in Bisbee. Shit. We’re moving up.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Mister Hollander.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLANDER
dialogues.text: (to Tucker) ‘Going to the saloon... Dan follows Hollander out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan trails after Hollander along the plank walkway.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: ...You got no right to do what you done. You hear me. That’s my land.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLANDER
dialogues.text: Come next week, its not, Evans. You borrowed a good deal of money. And I got rights to recompense. Dan grabs Hollander by the collar--

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: .»..You dammed up my creek. You shut off my water. How am I supposed to-- Tucker come from behind, grabbing Dan, throwing him backw Hollander dusts himself off.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLANDER
dialogues.text: ...Before water touches your land, Evans, it resides and flows on mine, and, as such, I can do with it as I fucking please. Go home and pack up. Dan holds out ALICE’S BROOCH.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: ...Let me just get to spring. I can turn the corner. CLOSE ON -- HOLLANDER, glancing at it. Not enough. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HOLLANDER
dialogues.text: ...Sometimes, a man has to be big enough to see how small he is. The railroads coming. Your land is worth more with you off it. Hollander turns and climbs the steps and moves through th saloon doors, disappearing into an office inside. Tucker watches Dan until he starts to walk toward his hor in front of Doc Potter’s place. CLOSE ON-- DAN. Fire in his eyes, he adjusts his saddle, waiting for Tucker to head around the corner, Then, he gr his SPENCER RIFLE and marches for the saloon entrance. CLOSE ON-- THE MARSHAL, catching sight of Dan.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHAL
dialogues.text: What the hell...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben Wade slips past Emma, out her bedroom door, moving toward the stairs. But his hand moves to his PEACEMAKER w he hears--

dialogues.speaker: DAN, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Hollander! Emma and Wade meet eyes. Wade proceeds down the spiral stairs to see-- Dan, wild-eyed, holding his rifle, standing at the door t leads to Hollander’s office... Wade approaches Dan. Dan steps toward the bar.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: You look a little bent, Rancher. You come to wake some snakes? Emma crosses down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Dan. Would you like a drink.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: No thanks. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Dan looks at Wade. Heart is in his throat. Sweat on his b What is he doing here?

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: ...-You got your horses back, didn’t you? And your herd? Dan?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: You killed two of them. Wade smiles. He places SIX GOLD COINS on the bar.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: They were thin. But this should cover it. Dan doesn’t respond. Over Wade’ shoulder, he sees Crawley the windows, moving toward the back of the saloon. WADE (CONT’D) What’s a day’s work worth to you?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: I get two dollars when I hire out.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: Here’s two for half a day. Wade puts TWO MORE COINS on the bar...

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: You took up my boys’ time too. Wade adds another two. Shares a look with Emma.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: Anything else you want to get paid for, Dan? Dan fingers the GOLD COINS. His eyes flick, seeing the Marshal enetering from the back door. Leveling a SLIDE-AC REPEATER at Wade’s back. Wade is about to turn when--

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: If it’s alright with you, you can give me five dollars extra.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: For what.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: ...For making me nervous. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Wade’s face changes, something wrong. CLICK-CLACK. Marshal Weathers cocks his REPEATER behind W Digging the muzzle into the his back.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHAL WEATHERS
dialogues.text: Hands up, Ben Wade. Tucker appear in the SALOON DOORS, PISTOL drawn.

dialogues.speaker: TUCKER
dialogues.text: Boss. Boss! Crawley and Kane come in behind the Marshal. Hollander emerges fromn his office. Tucker hoots, thrilled.

dialogues.speaker: TUCKER
dialogues.text: Ben Wade captured in Bisbee! The outlaw glares at Dan who lets out a breath. He keeps his eyes on him as he raises his hands in the ai

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: Laugh while you can. Kane grabs Wade’s Peacemaker as Crawley locks a pair of H CUFFS on his wrists. the Marshall grabs Crawley--

dialogues.speaker: MARSHAL
dialogues.text: Get the wagon and make sure every weapon we got is shoot ready. I’1l meet you out front of the office. (to the others) We got to get him out of here.

dialogues.speaker: TUCKER
dialogues.text: We should shoot him right now. Put a bullet in his noggin.

dialogues.speaker: MCELROY
dialogues.text: You do that, every man, woman and child in this shit-piss town will be slaughtered by daybreak. Dan and the others look to-- Byron McElroy in the doorway. Blood seeps from the bandag around his gut. He holds his shotgun. Potter trails after him, trying to finish his dressing. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BUTTERFIELD
dialogues.text: (pointing at Wade) Twenty two robberies. Four hundred thousand in losses, more in delays. The Southern Pacific wants Ben Wade convicted in a Federal Court. Hung in public. An example made. And we will pay to make it happen.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: (to Dan) You notice he never mentioned the lives I’ve taken?

dialogues.speaker: MARSHAL
dialogues.text: I need three more men. (grabs Wade) Let’s go. The Marshal escorts Wade toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLANDER
dialogues.text: You can have Tucker.

dialogues.speaker: MCELROY
dialogues.text: I’m coming. So you need only one.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHAL
dialogues.text: You’ re wounded, Mister McElroy.

dialogues.speaker: MCELROY
dialogues.text: I can ride a goddam horse as easy as I can sit here.

dialogues.speaker: BUTTERFIELD
dialogues.text: He knows Wade. You need him.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHAL
dialogues.text: If he goes, Potter’s coming.

dialogues.speaker: TUCKER
dialogues.text: Doc can’t shoot shit.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: I was the best shot in my regiment. I’ll come. For two hundred dollars. Everybody turns to Dan--

dialogues.speaker: BUTTERFIELD
dialogues.text: You fight for the North or South? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Dan looks at the Southern Railroad pin on Butterfield’s jacket. Still, he can’t lie.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: ...North.

dialogues.speaker: BUTTERFIELD
dialogues.text: We’re Southern in name, but Chicago owned. (to the others) Fine. Two hundred.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: BUTTERFIELD
dialogues.text: Thank me when its done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan watches as the Marshal ushers Wade across the street. Nearby, Crawley and Kane hustle to prepare a stagecoach, tying chain around it to secure the doors.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHAL
dialogues.text: Hurry up, Kane. CRACK! A SHOT RINGS OUT. It’s Charlie Prince, tearing dow the street on his horse, a SMOKING SCHOFIELD PISTOL in hi hands. He gallops down main street, townspeople clearing.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE PRINCE
dialogues.text: This town’s gonna burn! THE OUTLAW GALLOPS PAST. Never slowing. He fires twice-- BANG, BANG! The first shot drops DEPUTY KANE right in front of the co The second shot takes down A RANDOM BISBEE MAN. Eeryone uinloads their weapons-- BANG BANG BANGG-- as Cha scoots away on his horse, into the hills.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: EXT. MARSHAL’S OFFICE, BISBEE - DAY Marshal Weathers muscles Wade to a waiting CARRIAGE tied chains and padlocked. Both of them spot -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Charlie prince-- perched on his horse a half mile out of town, watching what happens to his boss. Wade gives him a and Charlie Prince nods back. The marshal shoves Wade inside the coach, then, as he cli onto the driver’s seat-- Emma comes up to the door.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Were you sincere about Mexico?

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: (smiles) -No. ...WE PULL BACK ON: Emma and the rest of the Bisbee towns as they stand back and watch the COACH take Wade away.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CHAINED COACH, FOOTHILLS --LATE AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: Marshal Weathers hauls ass along a CATTLE TRAIL, ever awa that Charlie Prince is following him on the ridge like a trailing its master...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAN’S CATTLE are back in the holding yard. Dan stands on porch with Alice. His two boys inside, pressed against th windows. WHAT THEY SEE: THE PRISON WAGON is passing their ranch, crossing a CRUDE BRIDGE over a dry creek bed. They also s Charlie Prince crest a nearby bluff, watching the wagon.

dialogues.speaker: INT./EXT. PRISON WAGON, EVANS RANCH --LATE AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: Inside the wagon, Wade glances at his HAND CUFFS and grin self-assuredly. He notices a tear in the seat. A PIECE OF COPPER WIRING sticking out. All of a sudden, the PRISON WAGON LURCHES TO A STOP. One the wheels has skidded off A CRUDE BRIDGE.  60 61 62 63 3:10 TO YUMA - TAN - 1.23.07 33.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PRISON WAGON, EVANS RANCH --LATE AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: Marshal Weathers curses, leaps down and attempts to free wheel. Wade glances out through the chained door, watching the marshal’s futile struggle... ...finally, Marshal Weathers turns to Dan on the porch.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHAL WEATHERS
dialogues.text: Hello, there. Evans. Can you give me a hand with this.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PORCH, EVANS RANCH --LATE AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: On cue, Dan walks out. Tucker and Crawley follow.

dialogues.speaker: TUCKER
dialogues.text: Whatever your wife is cooking in there smells good, Evans. Tucker and Crawley laugh.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BLUFF, EVANS RANCH --LATE AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: Charlie Prince squints to get a look at what’s going on a the men from the ranch disappear behind the listing PRISO WAGON and begin to push it back up onto the bridge.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PRISON WAGON, EVANS RANCH --LATE AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: Wade quickly pockets the length of COPPER WIRING as Marsh Weathers discreetly UNLOCKS the prison wagon door and hau Wade out. Crawley exchanges hats with the outlaw... ...-now Marshal Weathers gives Tucker the key to WADE’S H CUFFS. We see Tucker placing the key in his shirt pocket.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: Remind me never to play cards in this town. Crawley now takes Wade’s place inside the PRISON WAGON... ...and Marshal Weathers PADLOCKS the door again. Wade wat the men finally push the PRISON WAGON back onto the bridg  64 65 66 67 3:10 TO YUMA - TAN - 1.23.07 34.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BLUFF, EVANS RANCH --LATE AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: The switch has taken just a few fast seconds -- and from vantage point on the bluff, Charlie Prince is none the wi

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PRISON WAGON, EVANS RANCH --LATE AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: Marshal Weathers resumes his seat on the PRISON WAGON...

dialogues.speaker: MARSHAL
dialogues.text: Thanks for your help, Dan.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: You gonna check on my family when you come back, right?

dialogues.speaker: MARSHAL
dialogues.text: First thing. Let’s go. Ya! The coach rides off, fast, leaving Wade behind with them. A cloud of dust rises.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BLUFF, EVANS RANCH --LATE AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: Thinking Wade’s still in the PRISON WAGON, Charlie Prince wheels his horse around, GALLOPING away from the ranch...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PORCH, EVANS RANCH --LATE AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: .»..as Dan and Tucker lead Wade up to the porch. McElroy Butterfield appear in the doorway. Wade nods to Alice, bu she glares. McElroy pushes Wade inside...

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: How long’s he have to stay.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: An hour. Make sure Wade’s outfit takes the bait.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: What happens if they catch the wagon.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: You saw where his man was. He’s still got to fetch the outfit. They should get to the Fort before dawn. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: POTTER
dialogues.text: His gang can’t do anything in front of the whole Sixth Cavalry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc Potter keeps watch on Dan’s porch with Tucker. Both m cradling RIFLES in their laps. Doc Potter stares at the smouldering wreck of the old bar

dialogues.speaker: DOC POTTER
dialogues.text: You have something to do with that? (off Tucker’s smirk) Hope you’re proud of yourself.

dialogues.speaker: TUCKER
dialogues.text: ...-Doing my job, Doc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside, Alice prepares dinner. The two boys carry plates the table where Butterfield is waiting... ...we see William, starstruck, offering a plate to Wade w sitting at the end of the table. He smiles a thanks. McEl sits next to the outlaw, his HAMMER SHOTGUN in his hands. Dan sits at the other end of the table, joining Alice and sons. He notices William staring at Wade. Wade nods to William and digs into his food. Then Wade looks up, no on else is eating.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: We always wait to say Grace.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: And we don’t presume to teach other people manners.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Aren’t we supposed to say Grace for murderers, too.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Grace is for everybody, dear.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Well, then why don’t we say it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Mark --

dialogues.speaker: MCELROY
dialogues.text: I’d like to hear it. Everyone looks at McElroy. Wade snorts a laugh.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: God, our Father, Lord and Savior, thank you for your love and favor. Please bless this drink and food we pray. Bless all who... (glancing at Wade) ...who shares with us today. Amen. Wade looks up at McElroy who’s watched him throughout... ...the others start eating their dinners. William glances Wade constantly. Mark just stares at the outlaw suspiciou

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: You know, if my pa wants to, he can shoot you dead. He can shoot a jack rabbit at fifty yards.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Shooting animals is a lot different to shooting a man, son.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: No, it isn’t. Not in my opinion. Silence promptly falls in the room. WADE (CONT’D) Ask Byron here. He’s killed dozens of people. Men, women and children. Miners. Apache.

dialogues.speaker: MCELROY
dialogues.text: There’s not a soul I’ve taken didn’t deserve what it got. Just the answer Wade was hoping for.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: See, when it comes to killing, Byron McElroy doesn’t think in terms of man or woman or even child... (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: WADE (cont'd) (pause) ...-he thinks of souls.

dialogues.speaker: MCELROY
dialogues.text: Corrupted souls. Like yours. I fight the devil on earth.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: As a bounty hunter for the Pinkerton Detective agency and eighteen dollars a day plus expenses.

dialogues.speaker: MCELROY
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: Every way of man is right in his own eyes, Byron. The Lord pondereth the heart. (meets eyes with Alice) Proverbs... twenty one. William smiles. Wade glances at the boy and contentedly l down to his plate. He tries to eat his meat. But its not up and, with his hands cuffed, not possible... He meets e with Alice.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: .-Dan. Dan sighs and rises from the table. Takes the plate from Wade’s CUFFED HANDS... and cuts the steak.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: Thank you, Dan. Would you mind cutting the fat off too, please... (off Dan’s look) ...I don’t like fat. There is a pause at the table as everyone just watches Da dicing the meat.

dialogues.speaker: WADE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...Mind if I ask how you got that hitch in your step, Dan?

dialogues.speaker: MCELROY
dialogues.text: Don’t tell him nothing, Evans.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: ‘Where were you stationed? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Dan hands the plate to Wade.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: .»..-Second Company Sharpshooters out of Lynnfield, Massachusetts. Wade smiles appreciatively. Dan crosses back his seat. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: My father was defending the United States capitol in the District of Columbia.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: ...Is that so. (beat) So what happened, Dan. To your leg, I mean. Dan looks to Alice. William looks to his father. Then-- BANG! BANG!...shots coming from the porch. Butterfield stands, frightened. McElroy crosses to the window. Dan waves his wife and children to stay where the are. He looks to the door, his rifle in his hands. MORE SHOTS. Wade, amused, just sits there, chained to his chair and the cast iron stove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan busts out the door to find-- Doc Potter, firing his R into the darkness as Tucker moves to stop him.

dialogues.speaker: TUCKER
dialogues.text: Doc... Stop!

dialogues.speaker: DOC POTTER
dialogues.text: ....There’s something moving out there behind the rocks. ...McElroy and Butterfield arrive in the door-- as they a look out, a wind blows a dead tree on a nearby hill. Tuck snatches Doc Potter’s rifle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside, the boys have crossed to windows to watch the men argue outside. Wade looks to Alice.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: Ever been to San Francisco? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: If it’s all right by you, Mister Wade, I’d rather we not talk.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: So you’ve never been to San Francisco.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: -no.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: I knew a girl there... Daughter of a sea captain. And she had these beautiful green eyes, the greenest eyes I’ve ever seen. Like yours. And I would look deep into those eyes and well, they’d just change colors right in front of me. All the colors of the sea. He stares into Alice’s green eyes and she can’t look away

dialogues.speaker: WADE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’d you say your name was?

dialogues.speaker: DAN, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Alice. Alice snaps out of his gaze. Wade’s satisfaction is clear He watches Dan cross to the back of the house as Alice follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan slams the BEDROOM DOOR behind Alice. He gives her at look, then begins packing a SADDLE BAG.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: ...For God’s sake. He’s killed more people than the drought.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: He’s not what I expected. He’s--

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: --dangerous. Dangerous is what he is, Alice-- and you and the boys are not going to talk to him again. Alice crosses to the dresser. Dan watches her. She’s upse (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: You can change your mind. No one will think less of you.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: No one can think less of me. He looks at her, then looks out the window.

dialogues.speaker: DAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Six months from now, everything’s gonna be green, Alice. Cattle’s gonna be fat. We’ll see the steam from the trains over the ridge. We’ll be all right. Maybe better. But we won’t make it through the next six days if I don’t do this. The door opens--

dialogues.speaker: DOC POTTER
dialogues.text: Sorry, Dan,.. Mister McElroy says five minutes. And closes it. Alice looks to Dan.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: You think he’s too much for me?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: He’s a killer, Daniel.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Then someone ought to have the decency to bring him to justice.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: ...What are you thinking.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: I’m not out there alone. (touches her) Have a little faith in me.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Ben Wade has a gang, Dan. And they are out there tonight. Somewhere. DAN (CONT’ D) If I don’t go, we’ve got to pack and leave, heading for God-knows-— where, dirt poor, without a prayer. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DAN (CONT’D) I’m tired of watching the boys go hungry. I’m tired of the way they look at me. I’m tired of the way you don’t. I’ve been standing on one leg for three damned years, waiting for God to do me a favor, Alice. He isn’t listening. It’s up to me. ...there’s a polite KNOCK on the BEDROOM DOOR.

dialogues.speaker: BUTTERFIELD, (0O.S.)
dialogues.text: Mister Evans. We’re leaving now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group is saddling up. Wade moves to his black horse, Tucker abruptly cuts him off. A smirk across his face...

dialogues.speaker: TUCKER
dialogues.text: No, no, no. This’s my horse now. ...and Wade just stares at him, then mounts another horse

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: (to the group) So where are we headed?

dialogues.speaker: TUCKER
dialogues.text: Ain’t none of your business where we’re headed. You’re a prisoner, Wade. You don’t speak, you don’t piss, you don’t goddamn breathe without our say-so. Understand? McElroy rides up, firing a look at Tucker.

dialogues.speaker: MCELROY
dialogues.text: We’re going to Contention. We’re putting you on the 3:10 to Yuma, day after tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: TUCKER
dialogues.text: Shouldn’t have told him that.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: Relax, friend. Now, if we get separated, I’11 know where to meet up. Tucker glares at McElroy who just rides on. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON: DAN emerges onto the porch with Alice. Their so are waiting for them. Dan looks both of them in the eyes. He can see Will’s attention is drawn by Wade.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Don’t be any trouble, Mark.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Yes, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: And William--

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I want to come with you.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Well, You can’t.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: --I can help.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: You’re fourteen years old.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I can ride faster and shoot better than any one of them. The Pinkerton is hurt and Potter’s no good, that railroad man is dead weight and that other bastard--

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: --William.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: I don’t have time to argue. I need you here. ANGLE ON: WADE, watching the Evans family. William takes last look his way and storms into the house. Dan embraces Alice and Mark goodbye and climb onto his horse. He moves embrace her and her eyes flick to Wade, self-conscious. REVERSE-- CLOSE ON DAN-- as they break apart, Wade trots loop around Dan past Alice, politely tipping his hat.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: Appreciate your hospitality, mam. I hope I can send your husband back all right. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Alice says nothing. Wade grins, then follows the others u McElroy’s vigilant eye. THE GROUP rides away from the ranch... .»..asS Alice, Will and Mark remain on the porch, watchin disappear into the moonlit hills. INT. BOYS’ BEDROOM, EVANS RANCH - NIGHT Alice is now putting the boys to bed. Mark is coughing ha It is a deep hacking that clearly isn’t normal, although Alice and William don’t seem alarmed. Alice gives hima measured spoonful of medicine. It’s all very routine.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: What’d Ben Wade mean about sending Pa back all right. Was he saying he was gonna kill him?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: He won’t have to lift a finger. His gang will do it. They’ re the most deadly outfit in the whole frontier. Alice shoots William a look.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Your father can take care of himself, Mark. Ben Wade likes to talk. Alice turns off a lamp... -..a moment after she closes the door, William sits up in bed, still dressed. Mark sits up and watches his brother. William pulls a PACKED HAVERSACK from under his bed. Chec on the RATIONS he’s wedged inside. We see an old SIX SHOO PISTOL stuck in there... ..-he glances at Mark, then quietly opens his window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group is now following the CATTLE TRAIL up a spur. St light the Heavens above for miles around. It’s beautiful. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ...but nobody bothers to notice. The lawmen have their ey on the hills around. Checking every shadow and shape. Whi Wade just looks bored. His gaze falls on Tucker riding his BLACK HORSE... ...and a smile creases the outlaw’s face. He gives a GENT WHISTLE, almost inaudible. And the his horse abruptly sto Tucker digs his heels, but the magnificent horse refuses budge until Wade gives another GENTLE WHISTLE. Tucker gla at Wade and he just does it again... ...and again Wade’s horse stops dead. Tucker fights the h but it’s clear Wade has total control. Stopping and start amusing himself.

dialogues.speaker: MCELROY
dialogues.text: Wade. Wade whistles once more to get the horse going again, the leaves Tucker alone. There’s a smile under McElroy’s scow

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: You really think the Marshal’s plan is gonna work, Byron. I gotta confide in you. I don’t. McElroy says nothing. WADE (CONT’D) My crew knows all the back roads to Fort Huachuca. They’11l catch the marshal by daybreak.

dialogues.speaker: TUCKER
dialogues.text: What makes you so sure they’11 come for you, Wade. Why should they. Wade smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MCELROY
dialogues.text: They’11l be coming. They’re lost without him. Like a pack of dogs without a master. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: MCELROY (cont'd) ...Doc Potter is pale with concern. WADE (CONT’D) Have another drink, Doc.

dialogues.speaker: DOC POTTER
dialogues.text: I gave that up six years ago. I’ma changed man now. A righteous man.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: Trouble the righteous have is being able to know right from wrong. Doc Potter stares at Wade, unable to answer. All of a sudden, McElroy turns to look back at-- A FIGURE following them on horseback about four hundred y back along a ridge... ...the rider seems to be following the group. Disappearin around bends or behind trees, only to reappear on the tra few moments later. McElroy looks to Butterfield who is alarmed.

dialogues.speaker: BUTTERFIELD
dialogues.text: Jesus, no. Not so soon... Dan looks to McElroy who stops his horse. The group insta goes on the alert. Weapons up. Fingers on triggers. The FIGURE keeps riding towards them.

dialogues.speaker: MCELROY
dialogues.text: Off your horses. Move it. Everyone obediently does as he says... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ...Tucker roughly yanks Wade down to the dirt. Doc Potter helps McElroy. Butterfield gathers the horses by the rein Dan, McElroy, and Tucker take up firing positions behind rocks and hedges. Eyes on the cattle trail. Weapons ready ...finally, the LONE FIGURE appears around the bend. ANGLE ON: TUCKER as he goes to shoot. Out of nowhere, Dan clamps a hand down over his rifle.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: It’s my son...

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: Now is that the quiet one or the one that doesn’t shut up. Dan shoots him a look, then approaches William.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: I told you to stay home.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I left home. I’m on my own now.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Goddammit, William. This’s no time for games. You turn around. Now. Dan gathers his horse. The others respectfully keeping th distance and riding on with him. Leaving William behind.. ...we HOLD ON: WILLIAM upon his horse, not turning around

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They’ re cresting a ridge now. And William’s still follow them a few hundred yards back. Dan brews with frustration ...not realizing that Wade is riding nearby, watching him

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: It’s a difficult age. Between the hay and the grass, my old man used to say.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: He’s stubborn. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: Well, you can’t plant a radish and get an onion.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Don’t talk to me like you know me, Wade. We ain’t friends.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: Only a stubborn man would keep his family on a dying ranch.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: ...He’s trying to help. He thinks he’s looking out for his old man.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: (smiles) You know why I’m so hard to lock away, Dan? People like me. Farmers give me shelter. Cattlemen give me food. Judges let me off. Jailers let me out. Law-abiding citizens out there feels strangled by their shitty little lives. And me... (grins) ...well, I’m like the bird that should never be caged. Wade glances back at William...

dialogues.speaker: WADE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your boy isn’t protecting you. He’s following me. ...and he rides on. Dan watching him. EXT. WILLIAM’S CAMP, CATTLE TRAIL - NIGHT William cooks his supper on a CAMPFIRE later that night. horse is unsaddled nearby. He burrows into his HAVERSACK pulls out a well-read DIME NOVEL. INSERT: THE DIME NOVEL featuring a SILHOUETTED OUTLAW on cover. A smoking pistol in each hand. Rain falling in she under the lurid title: “THE OUTLAW’S REVENGE!” William consumes the pages of the DIME NOVEL with an exci grin, glancing at a FLICKERING LIGHT on the trail ahead..  78 3:10 TO YUMA - TAN - 1.23.07 48.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...it’s the group’s CAMPFIRE. Everyone’s asleep, except f Wade who’s staring up at the endless blanket of stars and who’s got the watch. We see Dan remove the ANTIQUE BROOCH from his pocket, gaz at it a moment or two. Rubbing it gently with his fingers

dialogues.speaker: BUTTERFIELD
dialogues.text: ...SO were you conscripted into Lincoln’s army, Mr. Evans? Or a volunteer?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Neither. Maybe both.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: What’s that mean?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: I was a volunteer in the Massachusetts State guard. Then, in ‘62, the Federal government was running low on men so they called in state militias. To protect Washington.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: And you got hurt. Dan says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: WADE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are you doing out here, Dan? You got a family at home. You’re not a lawman. You don’t work for the Railroad. Or Pinkerton.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Maybe I don’t like the idea of men like you on the loose.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: It’s man’s nature to take what he wants. That’s how we’re born.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Well. I make an honest living. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: Maybe honest. But I don’t think it’s a living. You must be hurting bad for money if you took this job.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Go to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: I have to imagine being in debt puts pressure on a marriage.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: What would you know about marriage. We can’t all be cut-throats and thieves.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: I know if I was lucky enough to have a wife like Alice, I’d treat her a whole lot better than you do, Dan. I’d feed her better. Buy her pretty dresses. I wouldn’t make her work so hard... (beat) ...yeah, I’1l bet Alice was a real pretty girl before she married you. ...and Dan just explodes, his RIFLE in Wade’s face.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Shut up about my wife. You say one more word about her and I’11 cut you down right here. Right here.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: I like this side of you, Dan.

dialogues.speaker: DOC POTTER, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Mister Evans. Dan glances aside at Doc Potter... ...he’s staring at Dan from under his BLANKET. After a moment, Dan lowers his rifle. His hands are shaki His breath calming. Wade watches him cautiously. Tucker has also woken up, picking up his own rifle.

dialogues.speaker: TUCKER
dialogues.text: Okay... It’s my watch. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Dan finds a place to sleep as far from Wade as he can get ...as he turns away, we see McElroy under his blanket qui putting the safety on his SHOTGUN. Butterfield sleeps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone’s asleep now except for Tucker who is sitting ne Wade, his RIFLE leveled at him as he sings to himself...

dialogues.speaker: TUCKER
dialogues.text: ...yes, they’re gonna hang me in the morning, before this night is done. They’re gonna hang me in the morning and I’ll never see the sun. ...and Wade just glares at him lethally.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: I suppose it’s too much to ask for a little quiet.

dialogues.speaker: TUCKER
dialogues.text: I'd be asleep in my bed if it weren’t for you. So if I got to be up, you’re damn well gonna be up with me, Ben Wade. (singing) I wanna warn you fellas, tell you one by one -- what makes a gallows rope to swing is a woman and a gun. Wade rolls over, simmering. We see him discreetly remove length of COPPER WIRING from his jacket, twisting it tigh around both his hands like a shiv...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...a strange GURGLING NOISE wakes Dan an hour later in th dawn light. He focuses on the noise to see Wade kneeling Tucker. Dan scrambles.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Jesus! In the next moment, McElroy lunges at Wade from out of nowhere with the butt of his shotgun. Wade falls off Tuck Dropping the COPPER SHIV. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The others begin to stir now, reacting with shock and hor to what Wade’s done. Tucker’s throat has been cut. Doc Po rushes over and searches for a pulse... ...he doesn’t find one. His hands close Tucker’s eyes. SMACK! McElroy boots Wade savagely in the face. The outla tumbles. And now McElroy starts to beat Wade, his vigorou movements re-opening his own wounds. Butterfield and Doc Potter hurry to pull McElroy back. Wade notices Dan deliberately hanging back... ...and a grin creases his bloody, battered face. That spu Dan forward, pulling McElroy back with sudden force.

dialogues.speaker: DAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s enough, Mister McElroy. McElroy stops, if only because he’s exhausted and weak... ...-he returns to Tucker and retrieves the HAND CUFFS KEY Wade sits up, nursing his wounds and staring at Dan.

dialogues.speaker: DOC POTTER
dialogues.text: (re: Tucker) We have to bury him.

dialogues.speaker: MCELROY
dialogues.text: You take the time to dig one grave, you might as well dig two. And with that, the group reluctantly saddles up. Wade ret to his horse, whispering to it soothingly. Reclaiming it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An AMERICAN FLAG droops over the sprawling army barracks Fort Huachuca. The dawn sun glinting over the still sleep town. About a mile away, we find... ...a SMALL SPECK racing through a canyon towards the town

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s the prison wagon. Marshal Weathers looks exhausted a sits on top, whipping his TEAM OF HORSES through the cany (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Crawley keeps a frightened eye out through the PRISON BAR the wagon. A weary smile creasing his face when he spots Huachuca in the distance. The marshal reaches for his WATER CAN... ...BANG! The shot almost takes his head off. Marshal Weathers tumbles from the PRISON WAGON, falling r past Crawley’s eyes as he smashes lifelessly into a CACTU ANGLE ON: CAMPOS retracting his SNIPER RIFLE from his per behind a LARGE BOULDER. Charlie Prince pats him on the ba watching as the PRISON WAGON HORSES slow to a grateful ha ANGLE ON: CRAWLEY trapped inside the PRISON WAGON. His PI drawn as he peers out the PRISON BARS either side of him. ...the gang materializes out of the rocks and canyon crev now (PRINCE, CAMPOS, SUTHERLAND, JACKSON). Swarming aroun the PRISON WAGON like bees on a hive. It seems they’re st unaware of the switch.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE PRINCE
dialogues.text: Get you outta there in a second, boss. Don’t you worry. Jackson grabs the PADLOCK KEY off the MARSHAL’S BELT, giv it to Charlie Prince who then goes to open the PADLOCK... ...BANG! Crawley catches Charlie Prince with a taut shot. outlaw stumbles backwards. Bleeding from his neck. The bu just scraping him. The other outlaws spot Crawley inside... ...they draw their guns, ready to finish him.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE PRINCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wait. He gives a nod to Sutherland who quickly frees the horses from the wagon. Now Sutherland sets the PRISON WAGON on fire... ...the smoke and flames swiftly engulf the old wooden WAG Charlie Prince stays close. Eyes on Crawley who starts to panic inside.

dialogues.speaker: CRAWLEY
dialogues.text: Oh, Jesus... Oh, no. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Charlie lunges and grabs Wades’ black hat off his head. He dusts it off as the flames rise in the coach.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE PRINCE
dialogues.text: Where is he.

dialogues.speaker: CRAWLEY
dialogues.text: Open the door. Let me out of here, goddammit.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE PRINCE
dialogues.text: Where’d they take him.

dialogues.speaker: CRAWLEY
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE PRINCE
dialogues.text: Mister, you better tell me where they took him or you will burn. The smoke is choking Crawley now... ...the flames rising higher every second.

dialogues.speaker: CRAWLEY
dialogues.text: Contention... All right. They took him to Contention. Gonna catch the 3:10 to Yuma Prison tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE PRINCE
dialogues.text: You ain’t lying now.

dialogues.speaker: CRAWLEY
dialogues.text: I ain’t lying. I swear to God. Now let me out of here. The gang watches Charlie Prince carefully... He turns his back on Crawley in the burning coach.

dialogues.speaker: JACKSON
dialogues.text: Contention’s eighty miles back the other way.

dialogues.speaker: SUTHERLAND
dialogues.text: We’d have to about kill our horses.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE PRINCE
dialogues.text: So we’1ll buy new ones. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JACKSON
dialogues.text: Charlie. It was his own fault he got caught. He made a mistake. He was weak. Charlie turns red faced toward Crawley, still moaning fro the burning coach. BANG-- BANG. He fires two shots, silen Crawley, then turns back to Jackson.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE PRINCE
dialogues.text: ...You think you could do a better job leading this crew? Do you?

dialogues.speaker: JACKSON
dialogues.text: Maybe. Yeah. Charlie Prince lunges quickly at Jackson, smashing his fa with his pistol, knocking him to the ground, straddling h He levels his two SCHOFIELDS in Jackson’s face. Glancing the others. Nez steps to his side.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE PRINCE
dialogues.text: You forgotten what you were before Ben Wade come along. You forgotten what he did for us. (pause) We’re going to Contention. And with that, Charlie Prince remounts his horse... ...and GALLOPS back the other way. The others follow in o and twos. Jackson goes last, not liking this.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. RACING ACROSS THE RANGE-- DAY
dialogues.text: WADE’S GANG RIDES HARD at full gallop. They are headed ba toward Bisbee, dust flying in a cloud behind them. We see town of Bisbee in the distance. Charlie Prince leads the gang into the mountains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William sits on his horse, staring at something in shock. ...it’s the body of Tucker. Slumped by the SMOULDERING CA FIRE. There’s some confusion in William’s eyes. It’s as i doesn’t quite know how to feel. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Just now, he notices several SMALL SPECKS riding towards on the plains below. He spurs his horse onwards up the tr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BINOCULAR POV: THE BEN WADE GANG riding hard and fast acr the endless Arizona plains, perhaps fifty or so miles awa ANGLE ON: McELROY sitting on his horse on a high promonto The others grouped around him. McElroy lowers his BINOCUL his grim face says it all. Wade smirks.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: Can’t say I didn’t warn you.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: There’s a shortcut we could take.

dialogues.speaker: MCELROY
dialogues.text: Shortcut.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Through the pass. Takes you right through to Contention.

dialogues.speaker: BUTTERFIELD
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you tell us this before.

dialogues.speaker: DOC POTTER
dialogues.text: It’s Apache country.

dialogues.speaker: BUTTERFIELD
dialogues.text: I thought the government gave them land.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: These are the ones refused to go.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t take that pass.

dialogues.speaker: BUTTERFIELD
dialogues.text: You’d rather us take the long way.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: That’s right.

dialogues.speaker: BUTTERFIELD
dialogues.text: --and let your boys catch us. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: The Apache are skilled warriors and marksmen. Even worse, these are the stubborn ones who stayed to fight. You won’t make it. McElroy looks through his BINOCULARS again.

dialogues.speaker: MCELROY
dialogues.text: We’1l1 take our chances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: A PAIR OF DEAD, WHITE MINERS lying by the side the trail. Their heads have been scalped. Their bodies le to rot in the hot sun... ...we find William staring quietly at the corpses as he r past. About a mile ahead, we can see the rest of the grou They are on the opposite side of a spreading ravine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group is now riding above a ravine. The scenery here spectacular, if a little precarious... Dan rides up to Wade, looking at him for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: Something on your mind, Dan.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Why’d you kill Tucker. ...Why not me. Or Butterfield.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: Tucker took my horse. (beat) ...Did you like him, Dan?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: No. He was an asshole. But wishing him dead and killing him are two different things. Wade watches Dan ride ahead. After a beat, Wade catches up to him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: Your conscience is sensitive, Dan. I don’t think it’s my favorite part of you. Just now, McElroy falls back beside them.

dialogues.speaker: MCELROY
dialogues.text: Shut your mouth, Wade. From here out, you want to talk to someone, talk to me.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: I don’t like talking to you, Byron.

dialogues.speaker: MCELROY
dialogues.text: Not when I have the gun.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: No. It’s not that. (pause) You're just not very interesting. Doc snorts a laugh.

dialogues.speaker: MCELROY
dialogues.text: That’s right, Doc. Laugh it up. Until he guts you like a fish.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
